g.text: LARS-WG) or negative (with WeaGETS) impact was projected using HadGEM2-ES
ferent WGs, changes in projected impacts on rice yield was about
5%. This is not a trivial value if for a big rice
5% national rice production would correspond to 12800 megatons.
The analysis of generated weather series revealed the abil-
ity of each WG to reproduce the distribution of the values of an extended list of climate indices (reported in
Supplementary Information) calculated on the reference series. The polar graph of Fig.
variate system created with the set of indices used, with indices plotted on each radial axis. In particular, the value
plotted on each axis represents the probability for reference and generated series to be the same for that index.
The closer the contour lines are to one (thick black circle in Fig.
), the more similar the probability density func-
tions for the two populations. Therefore, for each index, values close to one indicate a good agreement between
shows how the WGs differed for their likelihood to reproduce the
most-probable value of each index (peaks in Fig.
). Some indices scored poorly regardless of the generator and
the site (probably in relation to peculiarities inherent to reference weather series). However, while WeaGETS and
LARS-WG offered a relatively more stable performance across the sites, the series generated by CLIMAK were
often the most similar to reference ones.
Results from a robust rank-based ANOVA-like method (factors being
Most of the indices were significantly affected (
frequently resulted as the most probable source of differ-
. However, for some indices (mainly those based on percentiles, since they are sensitive to
extreme values, like tx90p - percentage of days having
bility observed. Some indices based on maximum and minimum daily air temperatures were often more affected
. For temperature-based indices, this was observded for monthly minimum of daily
minima (TNN), as well as for monthly maximum of daily maxima (TXX).
Agreement between generated and reference baselines. Line colors indicate weather generators
(WG; C: CLIMAK; L: LARS-WG; W: WeaGETS), whereas line style corresponds to sites. (
weather series for each index (one monthly index for each axis with code labels as reported in Supplementary
Information); solid black lines indicate perfect fit to reference data. (
) Distribution density of the fit of all the
indices analyzed (the closer to one, the more the whole set of reference distributions is reproduced by the WGs).
